EFFECT ON OTHER DOCUMENTS
IRM 1.31.7, dated March 25, 2020, is superseded. The following IPUs are incorporated into this IRM: IPU 20U0899 issued from August 2020.
These procedures are primarily for the staff in the Custodial HQ Accounting section of the Chief Financial Officer Organization.
Associate Chief Financial Officer, Financial Management
Program Scope and Objectives
Operating Procedures for the Custodial HQ Accounting Section in the National Headquarters Office 1.31.7 page 1
and (

) Purpose: This IRM provides background information, objectives and standards for the Redesigned Revenue Accounting Control System (RRACS). This also contains procedural steps for the Custodial HQ Accounting section to when entering data into RRACS, as well as procedures relating to system security, research, balancing, data entry and data source location. (
) Audience: The Custodial HQ Accounting section uses, develops and maintains this IRM. (
) Policy Owner: CFO (
) Program Owner: Associate CFO, Financial Management (
) Primary Stakeholders: The primary stakeholders are employees who utilize RRACS data. (
) Program Goals: The goal of this IRM is to provide guidance to ensure the accuracy of data entered into RRACS. (
) The Budget and Accounting Procedures Act of

, further amended in by the Federal Manager’s Financial Integrity Act, assigned the heads of executive agencies the responsibility for establishing and maintaining systems of accounting and internal controls. (

) The accounting systems and associated internal controls are designed to ensure compliance with administrative and legal requirements of the IRS, Treasury Department, the Government Accountability Office (GAO), and Office of Management and Budget (OMB). (

a. CFO and Deputy CFO b. Associate CFO for Financial Management c. Deputy ACFO for Custodial Financial Management d. Director, Custodial Accounting e. Chief, Custodial HQ Accounting section f. Chief, Custodial Reporting g. Custodial HQ Accounting section staff
The CFO and Deputy CFO are responsible for establishing ﬁnancial policy for the management and reporting of the custodial assets.
) Associate CFO for Management (

) The Associate CFO for Financial Management is responsible for establishing, maintaining and ensuring compliance with custodial revenue policy and proce- dures for internal accounting operations and ﬁnancial reporting, and provides direction on ﬁnancial management; ensures ﬁnancial products are properly presented and maintained; and ﬁnancial systems are compliant with federal standards.
) Associate CFO Custodial Financial Management (
) The Deputy Associate CFO for Custodial Financial Management ensures proper accounting and timely reporting of IRS custodial activities.
) Custodial Accounting (

) The Director, Custodial Accounting ensures compliance with federal ﬁnancial management and reporting activities related to CA and is responsible for the internal/external reporting requirements and the preparation of the monthly/ annual ﬁnancial statements.
) Custodial HQ Accounting (
) The Chief, Custodial HQ Accounting section, coordinates custodial revenue accounting activities focusing on CFO headquarters and CFO RACS unit counting transactions and reconciliations.
) Custodial Reporting (

) The Chief, Custodial Reporting section, compiles and prepares the IRS Statement of Custodial Activity to present to Treasury, Congress and GAO accurate tax revenue receipt and disbursement activity administered by the IRS.
) Custodial HQ Accounting (
) The Custodial HQ Accounting section staff serve as database administrators (DBAs) and have access to the RRACS DBA main menu(s). (

) Each DBA is responsible for: a. Accepting responsibility for a password to the DBA menu. b. Exercising extreme caution when changing database information. c. Correcting records containing identiﬁcation and status errors. d. Ensuring the default account period is properly set. e. Ensuring all assigned journals are complete prior to initiating month-end closing. f. Verifying the accuracy and completeness of accounting data. g. Monitoring all RRACS electronic data input and output and making all necessary reversals. h. Establishing and maintaining up to date procedures for end of month (EOM). Note: To maintain EOM procedures, the HQ Accounting analyst will review prior procedures; use the track changes feature for any updates; share the updated procedures with the Custodial HQ counting, Chief and save a copy of the ﬁnal update. i. Reviewing database lists for invalid entries, and initiating corrective as necessary.

Management (

) Program Reports: RRACS is the main source for accounting information in IRS and Standard General Ledger (SGL) accounts. Data entered in RRACS may also be received from external sources and agencies. (

) Program Effectiveness: Any data entered in RRACS or Treasury (CARS) is saved and reviewed for accuracy, including documentation that supports the entry. RRACS reports can also be generated to ensure balancing. Controls (

) The Redesigned Revenue Accounting Control System provides accounting control for all revenue and refund transactions. The database consists of general ledger accounts that is maintained in systems located at the Enterprise Computing Center/Martinsburg Computing Center (ECC/MCC) and the RRACS database also stores transactions for researching, balancing accounts and generating reports. Objectives (

) The system is designed to meet the following Treasury Department objectives: a. Full disclosure of the ﬁnancial results of operations through an orderly system of controlling and recording ﬁnancial transactions on an accrual basis. b. Effective control over and accountability for funds, property and other assets, obligations, liabilities, expenditures, costs and revenues. c. Production of adequate and timely ﬁnancial reports to meet the needs and objectives of internal management and to comply with external re- quirements. d. Production of reliable data for budget reporting to the Treasury Depart- ment, OMB and other stakeholders. e. Coordination of accounting with the Treasury’s planning, programming, budgeting, and statistical reporting functions, including consistent classiﬁ- cations of data. f. Development of cost data for use in measuring results of operations performance of functions. g. Compliance with statutory and Joint Financial Management Improvement Program core ﬁnancial system requirements. (
) Management has the responsibility for providing a system of internal account- ing controls to ensure compliance and sound ﬁnancial management.

) Management has the responsibility for providing a system of internal account- ing controls to ensure compliance and sound ﬁnancial management. (

) Management can help achieve an adequate level of internal control by assigning operating responsibilities to individual employees, establishing employee training program incentives and rotating or reviewing transactions deemed essential. (

) Controls must be integrated into daily operations to ensure that basic documents are accurate and transactions are entered correctly into the system. Internal accounting control has the following four basic elements: a. No one individual or group should have exclusive control over any action. b. Neither custodianship nor operating responsibilities should be conﬁned the person who is responsible for record keeping.

1.31 CFO Internal Policy and Procedures

c. Every internal check or accounting control must meet tests of practicality. It should not discourage employee responsibility, close the door on indi- vidual judgment, nor result in an added operating cost that is disproportionate to risks. d. Internal controls should be maintained in a dynamic state. Periodically, existing controls should be reevaluated and if necessary, reconstructed harmony with changing conditions. Reevaluation of internal controls is especially important in CA activities due to tax system modernization components under development. (

) Adequate control in Custodial Accounting involves ensuring that all revenues are recorded but also provides an adequate basis for making sure the govern- ment collects tax liabilities due. The revenue accrual basis of accounting ensures this result by establishing accounting control at the time revenues collectible or received. (

) The control over assets recorded in the general ledger accounts must ensure that these assets remain in the possession of the government. Adequate measures are taken for their preservation, and assets are not written off or otherwise disposed of without proper authorization and follow-up where appro- priate. Control (
) The following are basic internal control objectives as deﬁned by the GAO in standards for internal controls in the federal government, (GAO-
G, September

). The internal controls should ensure: a. Effectiveness and efficiency of operations including the use of the entity’s resources. b. Reliability of ﬁnancial reporting, including reports on budget execution, ﬁnancial statements, and other reports for internal and external use. c. Compliance with applicable laws and regulations. d. The ﬁve principles of internal controls include: Monitoring; Information and Communication; Control Activities; Risk Assessment and Control vironment. Note: For more information on the ﬁve principles of internal control, see the GAO website: https://www.gao.gov/products/GAO-

Reliability of ﬁnancial reporting, including reports on budget execution, ﬁnancial statements, and other reports for internal and external use. c. Compliance with applicable laws and regulations. d. The ﬁve principles of internal controls include: Monitoring; Information and Communication; Control Activities; Risk Assessment and Control En
vironment.
Note: For more information on the ﬁve principles of internal control, see the GAO website: https://www.gao.gov/products/GAO-14-704G .

) While management has the primary responsibility for providing a system of internal controls, all personnel have a responsibility for understanding and ensuring internal controls are functioning as intended and adhered to. (

) To assist the Custodial HQ Accounting section staff in carrying out internal control responsibilities, a condensed version of the key standards of internal control developed by the GAO are as follows: a. Documentation. The operation of the function, system or project is clearly described in writing. Documentation describes what goes in the system, how it is processed and what is to come out. b. Records of Transactions. Important events or transactions are promptly recorded and classiﬁed in accordance with documented procedures. c. Execution of Transactions. Events or transactions are authorized and executed only by persons with authority to do so.

) While management has the primary responsibility for providing a system of internal controls, all personnel have a responsibility for understanding and ensuring internal controls are functioning as intended and adhered to. (

) To assist the Custodial HQ Accounting section staff in carrying out internal control responsibilities, a condensed version of the key standards of internal control developed by the GAO are as follows:

a. Documentation. The operation of the function, system or project is clearly described in writing. Documentation describes what goes in the system, how it is processed and what is to come out. b. Records of Transactions. Important events or transactions are promptly recorded and classiﬁed in accordance with documented procedures. c. Execution of Transactions. Events or transactions are authorized and executed only by persons with authority to do so.
Operating Procedures for the Custodial HQ Accounting Section in the National Headquarters Office 1.31.7 page 5

d. Separation of Duties. Key duties and responsibilities in authorizing, pro- cessing, recording, and reviewing transactions are separated among individuals. e. Supervision. Qualiﬁed supervision is provided. f. Competent Personnel. Managers and employees are knowledgeable, have professional integrity, and receive adequate training to complete assigned work. g. Accountability for Resources. Records are kept to showing custody and use of resources. The records are periodically reviewed to determine reli- ability. h. Audit Resolution. Actions are taken for agreed to recommendations resulting from the TIGTA, or GAO reviews. (

) Each employee should review the above standards, apply them when appropri- ate, and implement the following actions if accordingly: a. Make changes where possible or recommend the change to manage- ment if weaknesses are identiﬁed. b. Look for indicator of control weaknesses during Quality Improvement Projects. c. Include reviews or reports of employees, managers, TIGTA, and the GAO in determining the adequacy of controls. d. Look at the conclusions of any reviews or reports and consider how ap- plication of the internal control standards might correct an identiﬁed problem. (

) To illustrate, internal controls used in RRACS include: a. The double entry system for general ledger accounts and periodic trial balances. b. The use of control accounts or memorandum records when prescribed ensure the accuracy of subsidiary or individual records maintained in the operating units of the service. c. Follow up, by responsible supervisory personnel, of error situations, im- perfections in operating methods, or changes in operations requiring alterations resulting from instructions from HQ or other IRS offices. d. HQ management responsibilities have internal checks to meet special local conditions. e. All supervisory personnel are cautioned to avoid redundancies in costly checking, verifying, and balancing accounting summaries with supporting documents. (
) The Central Accounting Reporting System (CARS) is a Fiscal Service effort to manage ﬁnancial and accounting information across federal program agencies. (
) CARS records Treasury Account Symbol (TAS) information for payments, deposits, and intra-governmental transactions. (
) The HQ Agency Location Code (ALC)
is a CARS Reporter for the Intra-governmental Payment and Collection System (IPAC) system. All IPACs to the HQ ALC are sent to CARS in real time and do not have to be reported on the SF
(Statement of Transaction) at month end.

Separation of Duties. Key duties and responsibilities in authorizing, cessing, recording, and reviewing transactions are separated among individuals. Supervision. Qualiﬁed supervision is provided. ) The following general security rules apply to all users of any IRS computer system. The RRACS is not an exception. See IRM
, Information Technol- ogy (IT) Security Policy and Guidance, for additional guidance. a. Each RRACS authorized user will apply for and receive a User ID and password on the Online

system. b. Upon receipt of the User ID and password, a user should access the MCC RRACS system and change the temporary password assigned by MCC’s (Martinsburg Computing Center’s) Security Administration. c. ECC password format rules are as follows: Eight characters in length must contain at least one upper case alpha, one lower alpha, one numeric and one special character. The following special characters can be used: $ @ # . < + | & ! * - % _ > ? : = d. The Resource Allocation Control File (RACF) password system forces users to change their passwords every

days. User IDs become permanent and will not be changed. e. RACF remembers the present and previous twenty-four passwords for total of twenty-ﬁve passwords. They cannot be reused when updating passwords. f. Protect your password. Do not reveal it to anyone, regardless of his or her position inside or outside the IRS. g. Do not use another user’s password. h. Users should never allow anyone to use their password. Every action someone takes while using your password will be recorded on the system as being executed by you. i. Inform your manager immediately if you suspect your password has been compromised. j. Data entered or actions taken on a workstation will be recorded as being transacted by the user who initially signed on. k. Log off the system before leaving your workstation to ensure the integrity of the RRACS ﬁnancial data and to prevent unauthorized access to the RRACS ﬁle server and MCC’s mainframe. (

In addition to the system security discussed earlier, RRACS contains the following additional physical security.

a. There is an initial password required when the workstation is turned on. Without a valid password, the workstation will not operate. b. When the workstation initially boots up, another password is required to get to the initial security screen. Note: The password will need to be entered whenever there has been no activity for seven minutes. c. Once the system is booted up and the initial password is input, the user must “LOGON” through a security package. LOGON requires input of a valid user ID and password to sign on to the RRACS Local Area Network (LAN) on the ﬁle server. d. Another level of security is provided by Desktop Observatory. As applied to the RRACS system, it allows one of the following three operational levels (proﬁles/user accounts) to be assigned to each RRACS user:
System Administrator (SA);
Data Base Administrator (DBA); or

Tech- nician (User). e. The RRACS SA has permission to start the programs for the Transmittal System, but does not have access to the RRACS executables or database. f. A speciﬁc display screen is authorized for each of the three operational levels. Only the authorized icons for each user are visible. g. Each RRACS user must have an accepted user account, which deﬁnes the user’s proﬁle, along with unique user identiﬁcation (User ID) and password. h. Invalid user IDs and passwords will not be recognized by the system and access will be denied. i. User accounts and proﬁles can only be authorized by management in each service center. j. Instructions for establishing and maintaining security access to the RRACS operating system is contained in the Security Chapter of the RRACS LAN Administrator’s Guide for Communications/File Servers and Workstations. k. Only the DBA group has access to the DBA journal. The only icons available for selection on the desktop are the RRACS icons, an icon to start a session with MCC, and a LOGOFF option. l. REMEMBER: RRACS executables are not stored on the workstation. They are brought into the memory on the workstation from the LAN when the user selects the appropriate icon. m. To run the RRACS server part of the RRACS client-server system, the users must LOGON to the mainframe at MCC. The user enters their RACF User ID and Password and the system allows them to contact RACF at the mainframe. RACF permits users to begin certain RRACS server executables based on the User ID group to which they are assigned.

) The basic conceptual user operating terminology for data entry actions include: a. ACCT period - A mandatory selection for most journals. Decimal point - Included if cents are present in money amounts. d. Tab or mouse - Used to move from one entry ﬁeld to another entry e. OK button - Used to retain entries in a dialog box. f. Post button - Used to validate all ﬁelds or selected ﬁelds within the window and post to the database. g. Shift and tab key - Held simultaneously to move the cursor backward the prior input ﬁeld. h. System date and time - Displayed on the window in the upper right corner. Neither of these can be changed. i. All entry ﬁelds are surrounded by borders except for read only or calcu- lated ﬁelds. j. Originating source (Deposit Windows) can not be changed using Edit. k. Minus signs are not allowed on the windows. See the DBA if something was entered in error. l. The numbers on the alpha keyboard can be used. However, the
-key numeric arrangement usually provides better accuracy for numbers.

) The following section states the business rules for using source documents to post journals into RRACS. (
) All journals need to be entered, reviewed, and stored along with the backup documentation that supports the entry. Tax Tax Credits) (

) Refundable tax credits are treated as payments and may result in a refund to the taxpayer by the IRS. For example: If a taxpayer qualiﬁes for a refundable tax credit, they could receive a refund from the IRS, less any tax obligation. (

) Ordering Rule: A taxpayer can claim multiple refundable credits on a tax return. An ordering rule was created to systemically determine which credit would be treated as an outlay. An outlay is the total amount of the refundable credits claimed by a taxpayer that exceeded a tax liability (OMB Circular A-
), Section

, entitled: “What do I need to know about outlays?”). The ordering rule applies the excess amount to each refundable credit in the order listed below until it equals the claimed refundable credit amount. If there is leftover excess amount, it is applied to the next refundable credit in the order. The Advanced Premium Tax Credit (APTC), (which is a component of the Premium Tax Credit (PTC)), is the only refundable credit with an advance payment and consequently placed at the top of the ordering rule. This was due to the advanced premium tax credit being recorded as
% outlay when paid by the CMS. Outside of the premium tax credit, any new refundable credits established will be placed at the bottom of the ordering rule.

) If a difference is identiﬁed, the Custodial HQ Accounting section analyst will request an explanation for the difference and request a corrective journal action to clear the existing balance. Discrepancies not resolved within three months would be scored as an aged item. (

) Disbursement (

) Most agencies use Treasury TDO to process their payments. Some examples of TDO/Agency differences: a. When an agency posts disbursements on their Statement of Transactions before the TDO has issued those payments. b. Conversely, if the TDO has recorded disbursements, which an agency has not reported on their Statement of Transactions, a SOD is generated. If the TDO reports an amount different than an agency reports for the month, there can be a SOD. c. Agencies has the ability to monitor their disbursements through the Agency link prior to reporting them on their Statement of Transactions. The TDO Agency link shows all the payments issued per ALC during particular accounting period.

a. When an agency posts disbursements on their Statement of Transactions before the TDO has issued those payments. b. Conversely, if the TDO has recorded disbursements, which an agency has not reported on their Statement of Transactions, a SOD is generated. If the TDO reports an amount different than an agency reports for the month, there can be a SOD. c. ) IPAC differences occur when an agency fails to report or incorrectly reports a transaction. Examples: a. If the customer agency reports a disbursement, but the billing agency doesn’t post a collection on its Statement of Transactions, the billing agency receives a SOD. If the opposite occurs and the customer agency doesn’t post a payment on its Statement of Transactions, the customer agency receives a SOD. b. When agencies use the IPAC (Voucher and Schedule of Withdrawals and Credits) for interagency billing and collections, both sides of the account- ing entry are accomplished by the customer agency and there is no difference in Treasury’s control totals. c. When an agency uses IPAC to accomplish those same payments and collections, a debit to one ALC and a credit to the other ALC occurs. If both agencies do not report its side of the transaction a SOD is created for both. If only one agency reports its side of the transaction, a SOD is created for the agency that failed to report the transaction. (

) An appropriation is an act of Congress that provides budget authority to federal agencies to incur obligations and to make payments out of the Treasury. The appropriation warrant is the document that establishes, by appropriation symbol, the amounts appropriated by Congress. The term fund control refers to the various policies, procedures, and records used to exercise administrative control over obligating and expending appropriations and funds. Fund control procedures are actions by OMB and individual agencies to assure that: a. Funds are used only for authorized purposes. b. Funds are economically and efficiently used. c. Obligations or expenditures do not exceed the amounts appropriated (by the U.S. Congress), apportioned (by OMB actions), allocated (by Agency actions), or allotted/sub-allotted (by Agency action). d. Obligation or disbursement of funds is not reversed or otherwise withheld without congressional knowledge or approval. (
) Each agency monitors the amount in the appropriation warrant by recording and maintaining the appropriation and making certain the balance is adequate for all incurred obligations. (

) Receipt, appropriation, and other fund account symbols and titles are assigned by the Department of the Treasury consistent with the principles and standards prescribed by the Comptroller General of the United States. (

) This is completed at the end of the Fiscal Year. A separate report for each ap- propriation account shows the balance whether it is positive or negative.
